content.question: Which of the following accurately compares how party systems affect citizen participation in two countries studied in the AP Comparative Government and Politics course?

choices.label: Single-member-district plurality elections in the United Kingdom limit citizen interest in participation by diminishing the number of parties, whereas in Nigeria, despite also having single-member-district plurality elections, there is an abundance of political parties from which citizens can choose.

In China, the Communist Party has limited citizen participation by remaining nontransparent and by not holding direct elections for members of the legislature, whereas Russia has a multiparty system that encourages citizens to participate at the local and national levels.

In the United Kingdom, citizens participate by directly electing the prime minister and the cabinet, whereas in Iran, citizens nominate presidential and cabinet nominees before they are vetted by the Guardian Council.

In China, citizens can run for office at the local level and can be members of political parties other than the Communist Party, whereas in Nigeria, citizens can be members of national parties only because there are no local parties.

content.answer: Single-member-district plurality elections in the United Kingdom limit citizen interest in participation by diminishing the number of parties, whereas in Nigeria, despite also having single-member-district plurality elections, there is an abundance of political parties from which citizens can choose.
